metadata.case_name: Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works (Private) Ltd. v. Workmen

facts.text: The appellant, Messrs. Sasa Musa Sugar Works (Private) Ltd., is a sugar factory in District Saran, Bihar, established in 1932.
In June 1942, a trade union was formed in the factory.

In July 1943, trouble arose between workmen and management, resulting in discharge of three office-bearers of the union, including Shams-ud-din (joint secretary). Matter referred to adjudication; discharged workmen ordered reinstated in early 1944.
In December 1944, trouble again; large number of workmen dismissed, including Shams-ud-din (now president). Dispute referred to Industrial Tribunal; reinstatement ordered in August 1947.

In June 1951, management discharged seventeen workmen, including Shams-ud-din (secretary). Trouble continued to December 1951; agreement reached: twelve reinstated, five (including Shams-ud-din) not, cases to adjudication.
Reference pending since September 8, 1951, before Industrial Tribunal between management and workmen.
On January 1, 1952, union issued notice to management with 40 demands, threatening go-slow from January 9 if not met.
Notice received by management on January 4, 1952; management contacted Labour Department and Sub-Divisional Magistrate.
On January 8, 1952, Deputy Labour Commissioner advised union to maintain status quo.
Go-slow began January 9 and continued till January 12, 1952.
Labour Commissioner visited factory on January 12, 1952, advised Shams-ud-din to call off go-slow; conciliation to start January 17.
Conciliation began January 17; agreement on some demands January 23; further in February planned. Go-slow resumed January 24-31.
Labour Officer arrived January 28, 1952; talks held, but go-slow continued. Reported to Labour Commissioner January 31.
Labour Commissioner ordered no further conciliation till go-slow called off. Labour Officer informed management it could take disciplinary action with Industrial Tribunal permission.
Management suspended 33 workmen on night of January 31, effective February 1, 1952, for leading part in unjustified go-slow, contravening Act, suspended till further orders.
Work improved for 4 days post-suspension; go-slow restarted February 5.
Management suspended 7 more on February 6, 8 more on February 7, same terms.
Management applied under s.33 on February 6, 1952, for permission to dismiss 33 workmen; February 11 for 15 more. Total 48 workmen.
48 workmen applied under s.33A on March 29, 1952, claiming suspension was punishment without Tribunal sanction, breaching s.33.
Industrial Tribunal tried three applications together. Contentions: no prior enquiry; suspension was punishment; go-slow occurred.

Industrial Tribunal found: no enquiry held, but full evidence before it, no prejudice; suspension not punishment but pending enquiry/proceedings, wages liability remains (no Standing Orders); deliberate unjustified go-slow in Jan-Feb 1952 during conciliation.

Industrial Tribunal: no evidence 16 workmen involved; refused permission to dismiss them. For 32: granted permission to suspend 7 days (per contemplated Standing Orders, Go-Slow Committee). Rejected s.33A.
Award dated September 22, 1952, published October 21, 1952.
Management appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal against s.33 award; workmen against s.33A dismissal and s.33 award.
Workmen withdrew appeal re s.33A; dismissed, confirming suspension not punishment.

Appellate Tribunal: agreed management contentions correct (tribunal can't substitute punishment; wrong to reject 16 for no evidence); go-slow finding not perverse, serious misconduct, normal punishment dismissal; but held suspension substantive punishment, s.33 applications mala fide as post-punishment. Mistakenly said management applied March 29 post s.33A.
Appellate Tribunal judgments: June 3, 1955 (Appeal No. Cal. 366/52), May 21, 1956 (Misc. Case No. 145/55). Dismissed management appeal.
Management review application filed; denied, dates error accidental.
Two of 48 workmen since died.

legal_issues.text: Whether Industrial Tribunal could refuse permission under s.33 to dismiss for go-slow misconduct and substitute lesser punishment (suspension for 7 days).
Whether suspension orders were substantive punishment or interim pending enquiry and s.33 proceedings, rendering s.33 applications mala fide.
Whether there was evidence connecting all 48 workmen (including 16) to the go-slow.
Whether prior domestic enquiry necessary for s.33 permission, or tribunal can decide on evidence before it.

petitioner_arguments.text: Industrial Tribunal could either grant or refuse permission to dismiss under s.33; could not substitute own judgment on quantum of punishment.
Wrong to reject applications against 16 workmen for no evidence.
Suspension was not punishment but pending enquiry and s.33 proceedings; applications filed promptly after suspensions (Feb 6/11, not March 29).

respondent_arguments.text: No enquiry preceded s.33 applications; liable to rejection.
Suspension amounted to punishment without Tribunal sanction, breaching s.33.

court_reasoning.text: On Industrial Tribunal's findings (no enquiry but full evidence before it, no prejudice; suspension not punishment but pending enquiry/s.33; unjustified go-slow), only order possible was permission to dismiss if evidence against all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal bound to grant permission asked if misconduct proven.

court_reasoning.text: Suspension notices stated 'till further orders'; followed promptly by s.33 applications; Labour Officer authorized disciplinary action with Tribunal permission; thus interim, not punishment. s.33A dismissal confirmed this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suspension pending enquiry and s.33 proceedings.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence against 16 workmen same as against 32; Tribunal finding of no evidence perverse.
Go-slow insidious, serious misconduct, cannot be countenanced; normal punishment dismissal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellate Tribunal agreed but erred on mala fides.

court_reasoning.text: No domestic enquiry held post-suspension; s.33 proceedings converted into enquiry; management must pay wages till case for dismissal made out.

holdings.text: Permission under s.33 to dismiss granted to management for all 48 workmen (2 dead) for go-slow misconduct.
Suspension was interim measure, not punishment; s.33 applications bona fide.
Tribunal can decide s.33 on evidence before it despite no prior domestic enquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Management of Ranipur Colliery v. Bhuban Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Management bound to pay wages till case for dismissal made out in s.33 proceedings when no prior enquiry held.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Permission required for dismissal during pendency of proceedings; application for approval of punishment; special provision for contravention.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed management's appeals by special leave, set aside Labour Appellate Tribunal and Industrial Tribunal orders, granted permission under s.33 to dismiss 46 surviving workmen for go-slow misconduct; management to pay wages till case made out in s.33 proceedings.
outcome.relief_granted: Permission to dismiss 48 workmen (2 dead); wages payable till dismissal case established.

key_quotes.text: go-slow was insidious in nature and could not be countenanced, and that it was serious misconduct normal punishment for which was dismissal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature and gravity of go-slow misconduct.

key_quotes.text: the only order possible on the applications of the management under s. 33 was to permit it to dismiss the forty-eight workmen, provided there was evidence against them all.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits Tribunal's discretion under s.33 to grant/refuse, not substitute punishment.

key_quotes.text: suspension in this case was not a punishment but was an interim measure pending enquiry and proceedings before the tribunal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies suspension as non-punitive pending s.33.
